awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Geometry Meets Channel Measurements: Comprehensive Modeling, Analysis,Fundamental Design-tradeoffs in Real-world Massive-MIMO Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
One promising solution to handle the ever-increasing demand for wireless capacity is to deploy significantly higher number of antenna elements at the base station compared to the number of users in the cell. This so called Massive MIMO approach creates extra degrees of freedom that can be used to "shape" beams, thus enhancing both the energy and spectral efficiency of communication links. Massive MIMO can be implemented in a variety of ways. One extreme is the concentrated implementation in which hundreds of antennas are deployed at a single location within a cell. On the other extreme is the fully distributed implementation in which hundreds of single-antenna remote radio heads, distributed throughout the cell, are connected to a common baseband processing unit, thus forming a distributed base station. In between these extremes is the relatively less-investigated case of semi-distributed implementation in which multi-antenna remote radio heads are distributed across the cell. While the massive MIMO idea has been around for several years now, our understanding of the performance of these systems is still limited. This is mainly due to the lack of real-world propagation models (especially for the semi-distributed implementations) as well as mathematical tools that can expose performance trends for different spatial distributions of the users and base stations, both of which are known to significantly impact the performance of these systems. The main goal of this research is to develop a transformative measurements-driven analytical approach to enable the efficient deployment of massive MIMO networks ultimately leading to better customer experience, via improved spectral efficiency, and greener wireless communications, via improved energy efficiency. All the key outcomes of this project will be widely disseminated through publications, tutorials, and industry collaborations. 

The proposed research will develop a comprehensive measurement-driven approach to the spectral and energy efficiency analyses of massive MIMO systems by blending ideas from multiple disciplines, such as communication theory, stochastic geometry, point process theory, and propagation modeling, yielding the following key innovations: (1) stochastic geometry-aware spectral and energy efficiency metrics to facilitate fundamental analysis and fair comparison across different flavors of massive MIMO, (2) new stochastic geometry approaches to the coverage analysis of concentrated, distributed, and semi-distributed massive MIMO systems, (3) new results on the channel characterization for distributed massive MIMO systems under different classes of propagation models, (4) extensive measurement campaign (tailored to massive MIMO systems) using a one-of-its-kind channel sounder, (5) fundamentally new channel models for semi-deterministic massive MIMO setups that will incorporate correlation of the pathloss and dispersion metrics, in addition to traditionally modeled correlation of the shadowing from user to different RRHs, and (6) new massive-MIMO channel models for the millimeter-wave frequencies. This project will thus combine the powerful spatial modeling tools from stochastic geometry with real-world massive MIMO channel models to compare and contrast the performance of different flavors of massive MIMO under real-world operational constraints, which will directly impact the design, operation, and management of future cellular networks.

por.por_cntn:
The general idea behind massive MIMO systems is to equip base stations with orders of magnitude more antennas than the number of users served simultaneously per cell so as to create extra degrees of freedom that can enhance both energy and spectral efficiency of these systems. In addition to the concentrated implementation, where all the antennas are deployed at the same site, distributed or semi-distributed implementations are also being considered in which multiple remote radio heads with a single or a few antennas each are distributed across the cell. These remote radio heads are connected to a common baseband processing unit to create a distributed massive MIMO base station.

This collaborative SpecEES project has developed new approaches to the system-level modeling and analysis of different flavors of massive MIMO by blending ideas from communication theory, stochastic geometry, and propagation modeling. Informed by the measurement campaigns conducted by the USC team, the Virginia Tech team developed new analytical models and approaches with foundations in stochastic geometry to accurately capture the effect of network topology on the performance of massive MIMO systems. The first suite of results focused on the system-level modeling and analysis of concentrated and distributed massive MIMO systems using new stochastic geometry constructions that capture the unique characteristics of massive MIMO systems. Two representative results include the analysis of fractional pilot reuse in massive MIMO and the analysis of distributed and semi-distributed massive MIMO under fronthaul capacity limitations. The latter provided useful insights related to the performance comparison of the distributed and concentrated implementations of massive MIMO that complement the findings from the measurement campaigns at USC. For instance, we observed that a more concentrated architecture performs better than a completely distributed architecture under conjugate beamforming and equal power allocation. Apart from the system insights, this work involved a new characterization of load served by the remote radio heads that can be interpreted as the degree distribution in an AB random geometric graph. The second main direction of research focused on using tools from stochastic geometry to develop efficient algorithms for resource allocation in massive MIMO networks. Primarily, we used the idea of the random sequential adsorption (RSA) process to develop a new decentralized pilot allocation scheme with desirable structural properties for the distributed massive MIMO systems. Despite its distributed implementation, its performance is remarkably close to the existing centralized pilot allocation schemes. The third direction focused on developing data-driven approaches to massive MIMO system design. Specifically, we developed a data-driven approach to beamforming and precoder codebook design for massive MIMO systems and explored its connections to the emerging area of theory-guided machine learning.

In addition to using known ideas from stochastic geometry, the aforementioned works on massive MIMO have also contributed new results to this area. As an example, the RSA-based pilot allocation work inspired the study of a new multi-layer variant of the RSA process. This variant naturally emerges when we try to apply the classical RSA setup to model orthogonal resource sharing in wireless communications networks. This RSA variant can also be interpreted as a novel variant of the well-known Renyi's car parking problem. Likewise, this project inspired us to derive the exact distribution of the distance from the nucleus to a uniformly random point in the typical cell of a Poisson-Voronoi tessellation, which was a well-known open problem related to the stochastic geometry-based analysis of cellular networks.

The foundational nature of this research led to broad impacts across multiple disciplines ranging from communications to stochastic geometry, propagation science, machine learning, and statistical physics. This project trained two graduate students, including a female, on several aspects of massive MIMO, stochastic geometry, propagation channels, and machine learning. Both these students graduated recently and joined top industrial groups. Results from this project were broadly disseminated through top IEEE venues, tutorials, seminars, invited lectures, as well as through a dedicated module in a new short course developed by the PI on the topic of machine learning for communication systems. The video lectures of this short course have been made available through YouTube. Results from this project are also being integrated into the graduate curriculum at Virginia Tech, such as in the new graduate course on machine learning for communication systems that was co-developed by the PI.
